title: Will FEWS NET publish a Food Security Alert with "famine" and "Yemen" in its headline between 9 August 2017 and 25 October 2017?
preds: Missed the boat on this one, stayed too high for too long.

Lowering: FEWS NET update on 'current observations' : "The Task Force on Population Movement reports approximately 2,014,000 people are internally displaced in Yemen, a 1.7 percent increase since June 2017." http://www.fews.net
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Lowering by 1% due to no major news developments and no recent FEWS NET update on 'current observations'.

Large areas of Yemen are either in the Crisis or Emergency zone regarding food security, and although the problem has been getting worse over the last few months. A date of Oct 25th is too soon to justify a "Famine" headline. As the FEW NET states humanitarian assistance is set to run until the end of October, and at a limited capacity through December. Near the end of 2017, or early 2018 might see FEW NET classify areas of Yemen in a state of famine.

The most recent USAID Yemen report states:
“Relief organisations continue to report ongoing insecurity and bureaucratic access impediments - including restrictions on the importation of commercial and humanitarian goods, and movement restrictions for both relief workers and Yemeni citizens - as the most significant constraints to relief operations. Of the 20.7 million people in need of assistance, nearly 2.9 million people live in districts with high access constrains, including approximately 1.7 million individuals in acute need of assistance, according to OCHA”  However, the data for food security and nutrition shows improvements over the year. “The UN agency’s September distribution efforts brought the average number of beneficiaries reached per month since June to 6.2 million people, an increase of more than 1.7 million beneficiaries from the February-May average. 
With USAID/FFP support, WFP has secured its voucher pipeline through December 2017 and food pipeline through mid-January 2018.” 
(https://www.usaid.gov/sites/default/files/documents/1866/yemen_ce_fs17_09-30-2017.pdf) Aidaroos al-Zubaidi, former governor of Aden, “is leading a movement for southern Yemen’s secession and has said an independence referendum would be announced soon and a parliamentary body set up to administer the territory.” 
“Hadi’s government has rejected the formation of the council saying it would deepen divisions and play into the hands of the Houthi rebels.” 
(https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-yemen-security/southern-yemen-leader-sees-independence-referendum-parliament-body-idUKKBN1CJ06T) 
This has the potential to exacerbate access impediments but not within the 8 days left of this forecast.
Adjusting as time to declare famine running short
Still feel that there is significant chance. Situation in the country hasn’t improved.

Reducing from the 35% I entered on 06 October. Conditions are very bad, but are classified as "Emergency", one level below "Famine". So long as current or programmed humanitarian assistance is being provided, the classification is not expected to get worse by 26 October.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
See @AB747 October 13 post and comments referencing UNSG statements at UNSC. Up-voted 1. Ports, airport and overland routes still vulnerable. Sharp adjustment down.

FEWS NET’s most recent observations for Yemen: “Media reports suggest payment of some governmental salaries has resumed in parts of Ta’izz, but payments remain very delayed and erratic.” (http://www.fews.net)
Considering there are 12 days left, and given FEWS NET’s current observation, it’s appearing more unlikely that a food security alert will be issued.  However, the United Nations Secretary General, António Guterres, told the Security Council yesterday: “While we have succeeded in keeping famine at bay, we have not kept suffering at bay. We have not dealt with the one major root cause of these food crises: conflict” 
(http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57877#.WeEPS0wfl-U)
“In Yemen, many millions are still suffering, despite assistance from the World Food Program.” https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/un-chief-says-donors-kept-famine-at-bay--but-aid-needed/2017/10/12/cfc6d678-af9a-11e7-9b93-b97043e57a22_story.html?utm_term=.100fcc7fabf5
The Secretary General’s speech was in response to the “request made by the Council in August for an analysis on country-specific impediments to an effective response to the risk of famine in Yemen, Somalia, South Sudan and north-east Nigeria.” It’s possible that the next FEWS NET food security alert will be related to the brief, and therefore, could include all 4 countries.  This special report by Reuters gives good insight into the issues with shipments of aid to Yemen: http://uk.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/yemen-saudi-blockade

no big events registered in the website that might change this outcome
Updating for the passage of time.
I'm more than the current forecast (15%) confident that this will happen based on General Awareness of events as reported in World News outlets
Foreign aid will be key to keeping at risk countries out of famine.  Foreign aid will more likely go to African countries over Yemen, increasing famine possibility in Yemen.
Not enough days left in the reporting window to not trend toward null.

Not sure which way to go on this:
A member of the UN special envoy for Yemen stated at the open session of the security council: “Some 17 million individuals are food insecure and over one third of the country’s districts are now in severe danger of famine.” (https://osesgy.unmissions.org/briefing-un-special-envoy-yemen-open-session-security-council)
The UNHRC said in its September analysis that the Yemen operation is only 47% financed  (https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Yemen%20Fact%20Sheet_September%202017.pdf) and FEWS NET are expecting humanitarian assistance to scale back after October 2017 due to funding. 
Organisations tend to use the word “famine” when financial support is urgently required - based on the comments from the UN envoy, along with the funding data, FEWS NET could issue an FSA at the end of October? 
That being said if FEWS NET data was reflecting what the UN envoy has stated, one would expect FEWS NET to update its “current observations” to a more food insecure statement rather than the current “availability of some basic food commodities…has improved”
I guess 1 in 7 is pretty close to what Fewsnet. Will do.as opposed to objective fact.

Lowering forecast: I think its likely one of the main reasons FEWS NET would issue a ‘food security alert’ would be due to lack of funding. Recent pledges would make this unlikely to happen in the next 18 days. 
To expand on the report @dcm linked; “The FAO and World Bank have launched a $36 million project aimed at providing immediate assistance to over 630,000 poor and food insecure people in Yemen. The grant will enable FAO to support priority projects, such as those in the areas of providing a food-security support and rehabilitation of water resources that will increase smallholders’ production, income and nutrition, as well as build the capacity of stakeholders involved in various projects related to the grant. Target areas will consist of 21 of the most food-insecure districts in the country.” (http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/1041473/icode/)
The Chinese government has announced a grant of 150 million yuan ($22.5 million) as relief 
assistance to Yemen, in addition to 5 million yuan ($750,000) for the UN World Food Programme and 2 million yuan ($300,000) for the WHO. (http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-10/07/c_136663828.htm)  However, still giving this a possibility of happening as the UN has “blacklisted” the Saudi-led coalition’s fighting in Yemen. “The coalitions actions resulted in 683 child casualties during 2016.” (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-41501672). The report, this year, has been split into two categories. “One lists parties that have out in place measures to protect children, which include the coalition, and the other includes parties that have not.” But despite this, the Saudi UN Ambassaord, Abdallah al-Moualllimi, said “We reject the inaccurate and misleading information and figures contained in the report and we express our strong reservation with respect to this information.” (http://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-saudi-un/saudi-arabia-says-u-n-report-on-yemen-inaccurate-and-misleading-idUSKBN1CB2BL?il=0)
Will be looking to see what the Saudi-coalition does in terms of humanitarian access in response to this, but I agree with @cpschneider, it would take several days to assess the situation.

Also FEWS Net report until September says that assistance has lower risk to phase 3 in many cases and only a worst case scenario would trigger famine (phase 5), which means that many things must go wrong in the few days left of October.

Reducing for passage of time. FEWS NET still classifies the worst affected areas as "Emergency", one level short of "Famine". They note that their classification  "Would likely be at least one phase worse without current or programmed humanitarian assistance". http://www.fews.net/east-africa/yemen

Supply of water can be associated with famine, typically in the natural resource sense.  There can be plentiful water supplies in the west region depending on precipitation.  Water is captured as precipitation runoff.   Control of that region can be largely affected by control of the water.  Currently, that area is dominated by Houthi and pro-Saleh forces.  The Gulf Cooperation Council may continue efforts to gain control of that region and drive out the Houthi as winter sets in.
Lowering due to passage of time.

still possible; greatest threat doesn't seem to be availability of humanitarian aid but access of aid to Yemenis.  I would guess that FEWS, whose reports tend to be much more conservative than the UN headlines/reports, would consider this at meeting some but not all 3 requirements for famine. https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/yemen-brink-humanitarian-calamity-says-un-migration-agency-director-general-sana
https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/fao-and-world-bank-launch-36-million-programme-scale-famine-fighting-yemen

FEWS uses the word “famine” relatively rarely in their alerts. Of the 314 alerts published under the URL at the end of the question since 2005, only 17 (5.5%) contained the word “famine” and referred to one or more countries directly. Two more alerts containing the word "famine" without referring to any country specifically. Notably, 8 of these alerts have been issued in the past 12 months - 6 in December/January 2016 and 2 in May/June 2017  (one alert from Dec 2016 referred to Yemen directly). It is not entirely clear to me why alerts appear to be clustered around certain dates, but I suspect that has to do with data availability and FEWS reporting behavior. If this was the case, the probability that a relevant alert will be issued before the end of October would be quite low. On the other hand, the outlook for Yemen for October 2017 to January 2018 is worse than for the previous months, which could increase the probability that FEWS issues an alert relevant to the question. As FEWS alerts more often than not use the word “famine” in contexts in which such a situation has not yet occurred, a relevant alert seems not implausible. 11 of the 19 alerts that mentioned “famine” in the past 12 years refer to “pre-famine conditions”, the “risk” or “possibility” of or “the need to prevent” famine.  The question is how quickly FEWS would issues an alert if food imports decrease or stop entirely in the coming weeks.  While this should not be the case according to FEWS ("at current funding and assistance levels, WFP expects to continue providing assistance through October 2017"), I estimate that even if supply was disrupted,  it would take FEWS at least several days to assess the situation and  publish the alert. With only 22 days left, an alert seems not very likely.
Consensus and only 22 days left for 25 Oct. There could easily be a famine alert on the 26th.

WFP report stated “While the observed improvement in the availability of food items in the market would help those who have the economic capacity to buy, but it has little impact for millions of severely food insecure Yemeni households who have lost their income sources and are relying on emergency food assistance. Nonetheless, better availability of food commodities in local markets enhances the opportunity for food assistance through Market-Based Interventions” (https://docs.wfp.org/api/documents/WFP-0000022394/download/?_ga=2.78516564.195614532.1506454117-1545756473.1480975899)  The WFP expects to provide assistance through October hence lowering forecast due to time constraint. FEWS NET has also stated a “wheat-only distribution is expected through December 2017” - given that FEWS NET acknowledges this is the case, I think a food security alert would’ve already been issued if they thought this would have a devastating impact on households dependent on emergency food assistance. (http://www.fews.net/east-africa/yemen/key-message-update/september-2017-1) 
If shipping data (when released) shows a big drop for September deliveries I will reassess forecast.

Key Messages
Large populations in Yemen continue to face Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or Emergency (IPC Phase 4) acute food insecurity, the latter of which is associated with increased acute malnutrition and an increased risk of excess mortality. In a worst-case scenario, significant declines in commercial imports below requirement levels and conflict that cuts populations off from trade and humanitarian assistance for an extended period could drive food security outcomes in line with Famine (IPC Phase 5). 
Large-scale humanitarian assistance continues to play an important role in reducing the severity of acute food insecurity outcomes in Yemen. In August 2017, WFP distributed in-kind and voucher assistance to approximately 7 million people. At current funding and assistance levels, WFP expects to continue providing assistance through October 2017. After October, a partial pipeline break is expected to result in the provision of wheat-only distributions through December 2017.
Field reports suggest the floating of the Yemeni Rial in mid-August has not yet resulted in major market disruptions or unexpected inflation. Field reports suggest this is at least partially due to the fact that many traders have been using the unofficial market exchange rate in their transactions for an extended period prior to the floating of the currency.
FleetMon ship tracking data suggest the number of bulk carriers, which typically transport most staple cereals, that have arrived into Al Hudaydah, Salif, Aden, and Al Mukalla ports sharply decreased in August. Nevertheless, the total number of bulk carrier arrivals in 2017 remains higher than in 2014. Moreoever, according to UNVIM, the monthly June to August average of food imports in 2017 is 10 percent higher than during the same time in 2016. Recent WFP reporting also suggests overall supply of major food commodities has improved on most markets in recent months.
The cholera outbreak continues in all of Yemen’s governorates except Socotra, with approximately 738,719 suspected cases identified and 2,118 deaths reported between April 27 and September 25, 2017. Populations facing both food consumption gaps and cholera remain at the highest risk of increased mortality.

I realize I am on high end here and I choose the latest link to begin
"Starvation, conflict and displacement threaten millions of people in Yemen, South Sudan, Nigeria and Somalia, but there is another looming nightmare: rising waves of epidemic disease, especially cholera, made worse by the constant movement of refugees  seeking any kind of respite from chaos and mayhem. Just how much more dire the situation can become may be known by the end of September, according to medical and relief experts, when seasonal rains in some of the afflicted nations make meager roads impassible, and further spread the water-born disease. The same seasonal rains also bring rising incidences of other forms of watery diarrhea, as well as malaria, and there are reports of sporadic outbreaks of meningitis and measles. The additional health hazards are placing further heavy strain on humanitarian resources that are already deeply inadequate to the massive challenge of aiding at least 30 million people suffering in and around the stricken countries with some 20 million—figures vary—in the direst need of assistance. Moreover, the kind of money that the U.N. is asking international donors to provide is not rolling in. Of some $6.5 billion in humanitarian assistance, including funding for health emergencies, that the U.N. has asked for the four stricken countries, so far only about $3.45 billion  has materialized, or only about 53 percent of the funding appeal. The U.S. share of the funding so far is about $1.1 billion, or nearly a third of the money so far on the table. Another problem: dealing with the disease epidemics seems beyond the capacity available to the United Nations’ World Health Organization (WHO), which failed abysmally three years ago to deal rapidly with West Africa’s deadly Ebola crisis, in part because of its close ties with governments that sought to downplay the disaster. There is no doubt that WHO is trying hard to stay in front of the disease crisis, and in some areas—Somalia and South Sudan—has claimed that the cholera epidemic is slowing down, as one of its websites puts it, “thanks to timely interventions by WHO, national health authorities and health partners.” But other health workers in the stricken regions are less optimistic, and in some cases—South Sudan, for one—argue that the numbers of stricken are still badly underestimated. Moreover, in regions that are wracked with internal conflict, and government health facilities are in an advanced state of collapse, WHO’s abilities are starkly limited, and even shrinking, due to its ties with stricken local governments. “WHO is inherently unable to bring major outbreaks under control in places where there is violence, conflict and state instability and insecurity,” observes Lawrence Gostin, professor of medicine at Georgetown University and onetime member of the WHO Director-General’s Advisory Committee on Reforming the World Health Organization. “WHO is highly dependent on national health authorities, and where there i a vacuum of power in local government, or when those governments are corrupt and even cause the health hazards, WHO simply doesn’t have the ability to end fast-moving epidemics. WHO also relies on strong national health systems, and these health systems are weak, fragmented or non existent in conflict zones and in places where refugees congregate.” “It is probably unrealistic to believe that WHO has the political and economic power to be highly effective,” continued Gostin. “In the case of cholera, it has not been able to make a difference in war-torn countries.” WHO, of course, argues otherwise. Nonetheless, a bad situation is fast becoming worse. The cholera crisis in Yemen, recognized as the world’s worst single-country outbreak, has some 630,000 cases so far, according to the United Nations’ World Health Organization (WHO), with about 2,000 dead as a result."
In a gloomy report to the U.N. Security Council, the U.N.’s top refugee official, Stephen O’Brien, declared that “we are seeing accelerating institutional collapse in Yemen, which is also putting considerable additional pressure on the response.” Only 45 per cent of national health facilities were fully functioning—a nebulous standard—he declared and “sanitation systems have mostly ground to a halt.” Beyond those numbers is the much bigger disaster of some 2.9 million Yemeni refugees and 17 million people labeled as “food insecure” by the U.N., including 7 million at risk of famine. They are  bearing the overall brunt of a two-year civil war between Iran-backed Houthi forces and the forces of President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, backed by a Saudi Arabia-led coalition that has had U.S. intelligence and logistical support. “We are in a super-crisis,” said Caroline Seguin, deputy program manager for the medical group Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontieres, a non-government organization that operates outside the U.N. health umbrella.

the Economist blog  discussed the UN definition not FEWS NET but there is a poltical dimension.
Today  Pres Trump met with the US and Saudi backed leader what does this portend? 
But I add it here as  additional objective criteria:
"IN FEBRUARY the United Nations made the first formal declaration of famine since 2011. Parts of South Sudan, the world’s newest country, are now officially in a state of famine. The UN says that some 20m people are also at risk of famine in Nigeria, Somalia and Yemen. According to the Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWSNET), part of USAID, America’s aid agency, 70m people worldwide will need emergency food aid this year; the highest level in decades. The declaration has galvanised aid agencies, which are frantically fundraising to be able to meet multiple crises at once. But what constitutes a famine?  In the past, writes Alex de Waal, a veteran researcher of famines, “a rookie aid worker or journalist, a politically partisan advocate—or a team of seasoned nutritionists and humanitarian professionals—could use the word ‘famine’ as they wished.” But these days, it tends to have a technical definition. The United Nations uses the “Integrated Food Security Phase Classification”, or just the IPC scale. This system is based on geographical areas and places them into one of five categories, from minimal (where most people can get enough food without aid, but some are having to, for example, sell their livestock to survive) all the way through to full famine (where, even with what humanitarian assistance is available, a large number of people are starving to death). The idea of the IPC scale, which was developed in 2004, is to make famine technocratic. For a region to be declared in IPC phase five—full famine—it has to meet certain criteria, detailed in an extensive 125-page manual. For example, the overall death rate due to lack of food must be over two per population of 10,000 per day, and the death rate for children under the age of five (who are most vulnerable to food shortage) must be over four per 10,000 per day. What this means is that data must be gathered extensively. In countries affected by severe food insecurity, UN agencies such as the World Food Programme and Unicef conduct “smart” surveys, going house to house, weighing children and asking about food intake and deaths in the family. In practice however, it is not so scientific as it seems. Interpreting data is difficult: for example, any specific count of “hunger-related” deaths can be questioned. And more importantly, collecting data in countries where people are starving is difficult, because they are often at war. So where fresh data are missing, experts use proxies, such as the number of malnourished children arriving at clinics, to try to extrapolate what the real figure is. That makes declarations of famine more political than they might appear. South Sudan may well have been in famine last year, Mr de Waal writes, but a declaration was resisted before now, partly by a South Sudanese government official sitting on the IPC body."

Sep 18th 2017by C.K. | WASHINGTON, DC and what is truly disturbing is this report about Yemen, Nigeria, South Sudan, Somalia A leading agronomist observes: "Yemen erupted into conflict in 2015, when the Houthi tribe rebelled in support of the ousted President Saleh against the new government of President Hadi.  The government forces have the support of Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states, and the indirect, logistical support of the United States and other Western countries, while it has been reported that both the governments of Iran and Eritraea have provided support for the Houthis, an allegation that the Houthis deny.  In some ways, this conflict has become a proxy war between Sunni Muslims in support of the Hadi government, and Shia Muslims in support of the Houthis.  Access to assistance, especially on the rebel side, is hampered by restrictions imposed by the Hadi government. 
Under the food security scale devised by a partnership of government agencies and NGO’s involved in humanitarian assistance in 2012, the crisis in these four countries has been designated as Phase 5, or famine level.  For this designation to be made, the country in question must meet these three criteria:   At least one in five households faces an extreme lack of food
More than 30 percent of the population is suffering from acute malnutrition (wasting)
At least two people out of every 10,000 are dying each day"
https://www.agweb.com/agday/blog/straight-from-dc-agricultural-perspectives/the-four-famines/
Dr Mercier concludes:
"Through July 2017, the U.S. government had provided $1.8 billion in assistance to these countries, through both commodity donations from the Title II Food for Peace program and cash-based mechanisms through the Emergency Food Security Program, both operated by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID).  However, donations to the WFP for this emergency assistance from all sources had only attained 51 percent of their $4.9 billion goal by early August."

Comments: See @cmeinel and @AB747 September 15 posts, links and comments. Up-voted 1 on each. See situation as still critical; safe margin non-existent and any sudden, negative event in the next several weeks could impact sitrep.

Food assistance outlook brief for March 2018 puts Yemen's food assistance needs at IPC Phase 4, therefore I'm lowering the possibility of an FSA before end of October. http://www.fews.net/sites/default/files/documents/reports/September%202017_Final%20FAOB.pdf

FEWS NET has published a map of  Yemen's food emergency situations projected for October 2017 through January 2018, and it does not project famine in any region. Remaining at 15% rather than going to zero because (1) the situation could change for the worse; (2) What if FEWS NET were to issue a headline saying something on the order of "no famine yet" or "possibility of famine increasing"? Source: Dateline August 2017 http://www.fews.net/east-africa/yemen/food-security-outlook-update/august-2017

Despite continued calls for both access to threatened areas and support for humanitarian aid, I don't see the formal 'famine' tag being issued before 25th October 2017 "Security Council Presidential Statement Urges Greater Humanitarian Access to Famine-Threatened Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia, Nigeria Calling upon all parties in Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia and north-east Nigeria to urgently take steps that would enable a more effective humanitarian response, the Security Council today expressed its grave concern about the unprecedented level of global humanitarian needs and the threat of famine currently facing more than 20 million people in those countries. Issuing presidential statement S/PRST/2017/14, the Security Council deplored that in conflict-affected Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia and north-east Nigeria, certain parties had failed to ensure unfettered and sustained access for deliveries of vital food assistance, as well as other forms of humanitarian aid. By the text, the Council reiterated its call on all parties to allow safe, timely and unhindered access to all areas and to facilitate entry for essential imports of food, fuel and medical supplies into each country and their distribution throughout.  The Council further urged all parties to protect civilian infrastructure, which was critical to the delivery of humanitarian aid in the affected countries. https://www.un.org/press/en/2017/sc12946.doc.htm
I'm no longer thinking a famine is going to happen in the next month, looking like the country is going to need to suffer longer food shortages before a famine is declared.

Not going anywhere for a while watching this drama... have a Snickers, make the folks at Mars happy so they can contribute to help mediate the Yemen phase 4 crisis.

"Large-scale food security Emergency (IPC Phase 4) continues in Yemen". Phase 5 is famine, but they are not predicting famine except as a worst case scenario.
See @AB747 September 10 post, links and comments. Very informative. Up-vote 1. Agree with focus on major ports. Aligning forecast. Black swan = Houthis. Still unpredictable.

Lowering forecast: The UN has described the “Saudi-led coalitions air strikes as being the “leading cause” of deaths in Yemen as the civilian death toll increases across the country. It also blamed the coalition for stoking a food crisis that has left 7.3 million on the brink of famine.” 
The report, partly based on a study by Queen Mary University found “air strikes and blockades had cut off supplies to rebel held areas and caused the majority of deaths in Yemen’s cholera outbreak.” (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemeni-civilians-bear-brunt-man-made-catastrophe-says-un-536398161)  New data from the WHO and Yemen’s health ministry “show that the overall spread of the cholera epidemic has slowed in the past two months.” (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemeni-civilians-bear-brunt-man-made-catastrophe-says-un-536398161) 
Plus, increased publicity on the situation in Yemen has the potential to benefit funding for humanitarian aid, e.g. Buthaina, the child who survived an airstrike that prompted a social media campaign. http://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/07/middleeast/yemeni-girl-viral-photo/index.html World Food Programme analysis of July 2017 stated: “WFP reached the highest number of beneficiaries so far during this crisis, and provided food assistance and voucher support to 6.03 million people in 19 governorates.”  Due to the campaign being 43% funded; “under the current prioritisation plan, donations will enable WFP to continue providing voucher assistance until mid-September and will cover the food pipeline for in-kind assistance through October.” (http://documents.wfp.org/stellent/groups/public/documents/ep/wfp285740.pdf?_ga=2.28563132.1679440993.1505073281-709468494.1493409857)  Will be looking out for a more recent WFP Country Brief and any news on Hudaydah and Salif ports.

Food availability has not changed much in the past few months. Markets are still functioning. Famine is a worst case scenario that would occur only if "conflict significantly disrupts or halts imports through the ports of Al Hudaydah and Salif, inter- governorate trade becomes significantly disrupted, and humanitarian assistance fails to reach populations most in need". The probability of all this happening in the few weeks until 25 October is pretty slim (though this can only be a subjective call).

I feel like this could go either way: I believe that FEWS Net is likely to issue an alert regarding Yemen, but I am not confident that they will use the word famine - likely "severe food insecurity" or "assistance required" or similar wording.

Yemen is in bad shape.  It's a failed state in perpetual warfare.  Investigating food shortages is an earnest task, but declarations of famine create issues that must be addressed.  Declaring famine is an act NGOs and government agencies must do in specific circumstances.  Nigeria, Somalia and Yemen are all on the verge on famine, but South Sudan had a period of official famine this year.  Supporting a famine in South Sudan is much more palatable than supporting a famine in Yemen, which is currently at war with our closest Arab ally, Saudi Arabia.  I believe declarations of famine are often political and a declaration of famine in Yemen is unlikely.
Poor infrastructure, military strategy, on the brink of famine already.  I say the momentum pushes Yemen over the edge in this time frame.

In order to issue an Alert with famine and Yemen something significant needs to change in the meanwhile. Note that the situation in Yemen is indicated as emergency since months, with bad medium-term outlook, but no alert has been issued until now.
So, is there the possibility of significant change? the only possibility would seem to imply a big cut in food imports, as the country is completely dependent on those. The last FEWS report indicates a slight improvement in availability of basic food commodities, albeit among many difficulties, so such a sharp decline doesn't seem too probable. However, the situation is unstable because of Saudi Arabia's attempts to blockade and US possible consensus (http://www.dailyrepublic.com/opinion/state-national-columnists/how-trump-is-enabling-famine/), so it's not impossible.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

A search of Google News for "Yemen famine" returns about 40,000 hits with a number of them in headlines. Those are news organizations that likely don't rely on any strict objective criteria for the definition of famine. Nonetheless, the perception is widespread enough and has been worsening that the conditions may creep over FEWS criteria. Just by the bye, I would take any information from Saudi sources about the situation in Yemen as more in the nature of propaganda than reportage.

Major swathes of the country has been in famine for months... The U.S. is showing unabashed support for Saudi's ramp up of bombing, even under current conditions. I can't see a reversal of the trend that has already brought us to the brink of famine, if not into famine. Even if FEWS NET is totally politicized against declaring it, I think it will have to make some sort of observation about Yemen and Famine in the country to maintain any kind of credibility, just within it's own staffed ranks.

"According to the USAID-funded Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWS NET), Yemen faces the largest food security emergency in the world. A significant number of people across Yemen continue to face Emergency—IPC 4—levels of food insecurity. FEWS NET reports that famine is possible in Yemen if food imports drop and/or conflict further restricts markets and humanitarian access." https://www.usaid.gov/yemen/food-assistance
It seems likely that the question will eventually resolve "yes" but perhaps not before 25 Oct 2917. If the "conflict further restricts markets and humanitarian access" within the next few weeks, then my forecast probability will increase.
January report used those words on Yemen and the food situation has not become any better.

I searched all previous FEWS NET alerts for "Yemen" and I only received 3 hits: 07/2011, 06/2015, 01/2017. The latter hit had both "famine" and "Yemen" in the title.  Food shortages (if not famine) are not new to Yemen, yet FEWS doesn't seem to have given this much attention.  I did score this 21% likely though because that's the increase in hunger levels since June 2016.

Citing the comments of @AB747     (“Saudi diplomats have devoted enormous time and effort in recent days to emphasising how much aid their kingdom has given the war-ravaged civilians of Yemen…The kingdom’s public relations campaign comes as the UN Secretary General is weighing a decision that could embarrass Saudi Arabia.”  Secretary General Guterres denied that he had faced pressure from Saudis, saying “there is technical work being conducted and, in the end, that will be presented to me.”    “Abdullah Y. al-Mauallimi, the Saudi Ambassador, has pledged to improve humanitarian access on the ground in Yemen.” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/28/world/middleeast/saudi-yemen-united-nations-guterres-child-deaths.html?_r=0)    If the Saudi’s keep their word, regardless of what the report states, this will be good news for aid agencies and I would consider that to lower the probability of this question resolving yes. ) I think this sentiment is good news from Saudi Arabia and this benefit will far outweigh any cries for inquiry and a potential "blacklist"...I am sticking with my estimate of 10%.

“Saudi diplomats have devoted enormous time and effort in recent days to emphasising how much aid their kingdom has given the war-ravaged civilians of Yemen…The kingdom’s public relations campaign comes as the UN Secretary General is weighing a decision that could embarrass Saudi Arabia.” 
Secretary General Guterres denied that he had faced pressure from Saudis, saying “there is technical work being conducted and, in the end, that will be presented to me.”
“Abdullah Y. al-Mauallimi, the Saudi Ambassador, has pledged to improve humanitarian access on the ground in Yemen.” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/28/world/middleeast/saudi-yemen-united-nations-guterres-child-deaths.html?_r=0) 
If the Saudi’s keep their word, regardless of what the report states, this will be good news for aid agencies and I would consider that to lower the probability of this question resolving yes.  On the other hand, the Saudi-led coalition recently said that the “bombing of the capital Sanaa, that killed at least 14 civilians - was the result of a “technical mistake”” (http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/yemen-saudi-air-strikes-civilians-children-killed-sanaa-faj-attan-a7916461.html). This comes after the Human Rights Watch along with 56 other national, regional and international NGOs have called for the United National Humanitarian Rights Council to “create an independent, international inquiry into abuses committed by all parties to the conflict in Yemen” (https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/08/29/un-create-international-inquiry-yemen-abuses) 
The possible inclusion of Saudi Arabia on the “blacklist” may lead to a consistent/deteriorating  situation.

Per bbc.com KSA air bombing took out all every functioning crane at the  Port of  Aden and Hodeidah the only large  ports where food can be delivered.
Food is required to be delivered through Aden to reach any one in Yemen. "Yemen usually imports more than 90% of staple food. But a naval embargo imposed by the Saudi-led coalition, fighting around the government-controlled port of Aden and air strikes on the rebel-held port of Hudaydah, have severely reduced imports since 2015.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-41000237
and"More than 70 humanitarian organisations have been working to help those in need. However, access constraints, damaged infrastructure and unreliable access to fuel, together with a lack of funding, have hampered their efforts.
As of March 2017, the UN's appeal for $2.1bn (£1.7bn) to allow it to assist 12 million people in Yemen was only 7% funded."
" A quarter of Yemen’s people are on the brink of famine, parents are marrying off young daughters so someone else can care for them and cholera cases are escalating, U.N. officials warned on Tuesday as they work to avert a Saudi-led attack on a key port. The United Nations has warned the Arab alliance fighting Iran-aligned Houthis against any attempt to extend the war to Hodeidah, a vital Red Sea aid delivery point where some 80 percent of Yemen’s food imports arrive. “An attack on Hodeidah is not in the interest of any party, as it will directly and irrevocably drive the Yemeni population further into starvation and famine,” U.N. aid chief Stephen O’Brien told the U.N. Security Council, urging all U.N. member states to help keep the port open and operating"
Hodeidah and Aden not functioning where will the food come in without elusive cease fire
See "expressing concern that the Government and Saudi-led military coalition continued to unilaterally deny or excessively delay entry to vessels carrying essential cargo, he called for the reopening of the Sana’a airport, among other points of entry, and for the safe movement of humanitarian staff.  Despite extraordinary challenges, more than 120 aid partners had assisted 5.9 million people.  The cholera response had established 222 cholera treatment centres and 926 oral rehydration points across the country. He urged Member States and other partners to contribute to the humanitarian response plan, “please and now.”

Comments: Fighting escalating. Port and airport crucial to getting majority of humanitarian aid to needed areas. Don't see success in UN chief appeal. Affirming forecast. World Bulletin, August 27, 'UN chief calls for reopening of Yemen port, airport': http://www.worldbulletin.net/world/193420/5-killed-in-2-car-bomb-blasts-in-southern-baghdad Bloomberg, August 27, 'Deadly Clashes Erupt Between Yemen's Shiite Rebels, Al Saleh': https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-27/deadly-clashes-erupt-between-yemen-s-shiite-rebels-saleh-forces
Clips from Bloomberg article:
"This is the most serious sign of a potential breakup that we’ve had so far,’’ said Graham Griffiths, an analyst at global risk consultancy Control Risks in Dubai. “It’s difficult to say whether they’ll be able to contain this outbreak of tension.’’
Escalating violence could drive Yemen, already devastated by widespread carnage and in the throes of a humanitarian disaster, to become an even more menacing entity perched south of the world’s biggest oil exporter and a major maritime artery." Al-Jazeera, August 27, 'Yemen: Cholera death rates soar in rebel-held areas - Ninety percent of Yemen’s cholera deaths occur in Houthi areas hit by Saudi-led coalition air raids and a blockade': http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/yemen-cholera-death-rates-soar-rebel-held-areas-170826072954685.html “A decisive and crushing military victory for the coalition and Abdurabu Hadi is unlikely even if the alliance broke down,” Griffiths said. “It’s more likely that a period of chaos and fragmentation would ensue with no clear victor. ” Al-Arabiya, August 20, 'Houthi militias detain Panama-flagged ship at Hudaydah port, no reasons given': https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2017/08/20/Houthi-militias-detain-Panama-flagged-ship-at-Hudaydah-port-no-reasons-given.html Reuters, July 11, 'Cholera may accelerate famine in Yemen as resources shift: U.N.': https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-cholera-un-idUKKBN19W1QF
Clips from Reuters article:
"“This epidemic is spreading further and faster than anything we’ve seen before,” McGoldrick, speaking from Amman, told a Geneva news briefing.
“What will happen is that this cholera outbreak will in fact exacerbate the conditions and the threat of famine in more places than ever in the country,” he said." "A funding shortage is compounding difficult aid operations.
The United Nations has received only a third of the $2.1 billion it sought to provide food to 12 million people facing famine in Yemen. Its $250 million funding appeal to combat cholera has yielded just $47 million.
“As a result of that, organizations who are in areas where cholera has broken out have had to use resources that they would have otherwise programmed for something like food insecurity or malnutrition,” McGoldrick said.
“What we are doing right now is robbing Peter to pay Paul.”

Maintaining forecast: From regularly looking at news sites, recently it appears that Yemen is appearing more often than some of the other humanitarian disasters in the world. With this increased media coverage, there is the potential for FEWS NET to draw attention to other places, such as Kenya.  However, funding is still a big problem and with the NY Times article, posted by @richtyge (thanks!), stating “Services that Yemenis depended on are gone, and the destruction has undermined the country’s already weak economy. It has also made it harder for humanitarian organisations to bring in and distribute aid.” Showing that the situation will only worsen without the conflicting parties resolving disputes. 
Funding may also be at risk from Saudi Arabia as they’ve been named in leaked drafts of a UN report for 2016 that said the “coalition is responsible for more than half of child casualties…”
The 2015 report, "threatened Saudi Arabia with inclusion on the UN blacklist of forces that harm children, Saudi Arabia threatened to withhold financing from major humanitarian operations, and Ban Ki-moon struck the coalition off the list.” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/25/opinion/the-slaughter-of-children-in-yemen.html) 
If Saudi Arabia threaten again to withhold funding (they are one of the biggest funders to the humanitarian mission in Yemen) and the UN do not back down this time on the report, there would be a major impact on providing aid to the 10 million who require assistance.
Only one famine alert so far.
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/08/23/world/middleeast/yemen-cholera-humanitarian-crisis.html The war is not slowing and in the above article reports people suffering from malnutrition

Balancing different factors, including this report: http://www.aljazeera.com/video/news/2017/08/million-yemen-face-threat-famine-170819050533860.html Also: "Yemen’s food system has collapsed, Farrell said, noting that even hospitals have been bombed, and it is “as difficult to get medical supplies into the country as it is to get food in.” https://cruxnow.com/global-church/2017/08/20/20-million-people-conflict-added-drought-means-no-food-eat/

As of June 2017, FEWS gave us the risk of Famine as likely. However, it does not give the risk as likely in its outlook through October 2017. one area of the country, the region around Taiz, is one rung below famine. Most of the inhabited part of the country is two levels away. Per the FEWS calendar, this is a time of agricultural abundance. For these reasons I am shooting a little lower than the average.
Already getting food aid. Sufficient rains and plant coverage recently.

The “International Committee of the Red Cross plans to send a test shipment of rice to Yemen this month in its first attempt since February to deliver food aid via the port of Hadeidah, which is held by Houthi fighters.”
“The port has been repeatedly hit by airstrikes from a Saudi-led coalition. It normally handles some 80% of Yemen’s food supplies as well as aid… The shipment was expected to leave Pakistan next week and arrive at the Red Sea port the week after.” (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-hodeidah-idUSKCN1AW1YK)  Depending on how the shipment goes, FEWS NET could still report either way in a food alert; stating something along the lines of “risk of famine decreases” (along the lines of @cdob63 forecast). Or if the Houthis decide they want the shipment, there’s a possibility of increased fighting at the port, which is one of the current observations of FEWS NET.  A European Commision’s Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations report stated: “During the first half of 2017, the number of reported airstrikes exceeded the total number of 2016, with the monthly average being almost three times higher in 2017. The reported armed clashes in 2017 are also 56% higher per month compared to 2016. Major incidents resulting in civilian casualties have occurred recently in Taizz (July) and Sa’ada (June and August). (http://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/yemen-conflict-protection-cluster-dg-echo-echo-daily-flash-16-august-2017) Maintaining forecast for now, as the European report shows increased fighting, which is the root cause of the famine, but the ICRC delivery may prove beneficial.

Now with 7 days to go before this forecast is resolved, it seems increasingly unlikely that a formal headline will update with "famine" and "Yemen" in the headline.  There continues to be many compounding factors, including food insecurity, but contrasted with the hard work of humanitarian efforts, the onset of the "rainy season and second cropping" as well as the ongoing Cholera outbreak, that will reduce the likelihood of famine being a headline.
More and more groups are using the 'F' word.
There is no slowing down of the armed actions in that country and currently it is out of the news cycle, hence, a higher chance that there will be famine in Yemen.

The last forecast they put out that included a famine in Yemen did not meet the "yes" criteria. There's still a famine risk in Yemen, but there's enough uncertainty with the way this criteria is resolved that I have to put a low probability on it.
Could increase if "major powers" are unable to influence or make trade offs with the proxy actors
Go with consensus and refine.  Test of how the system works.

Famine will be declared in Yemen or parts of Yemen in the coming months if the security situation deteriorates further and international aid groups will be forced to evacuate. As it is there are still enough resources left to stave off a full-fledged famine for at least the coming six months. However, if the security situation worsenes and international interest remains as low as it is now, famine will ensue.
Some sections of the country are one stage away from famine. Famine needs conflict to increase ("only" emergency if stays same or diminishes).

Clips from Vanguard article:
"It called on all parties involved in the various conflicts to “respect and protect medical facilities and personnel and their means of transport and equipment.” 
The declaration, based on a Swedish initiative and subject to tough negotiations, was the first time the UN has formally established a link between famine and conflict in the region. “The Security Council underlines the obligations of all parties to armed conflict to respect and protect civilians,” it said. 
It went on to issue a call for “all parties in Yemen, South Sudan, Somalia and northeast Nigeria to urgently take steps that would enable a more effective humanitarian response.” 
The council also called on UN members to make good on their pledge of aid to help tackle the burgeoning threat of famine. According to the UN’s humanitarian affairs and emergency relief coordinator, only $2.5 billion have so far been paid up by donors to tackle the crisis, out of a total of $4.9 billion urgently needed." Famine in Yemen has been predicted for months and there are barriers to delivering aid to the country. In March, the Red Cross reported that Yemen was potentially only 3 months away from famine (http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/03/yemen-somalia-months-famine-170322125343027.html). In July, the UN stated that they are unable to deliver vaccines to the nation due to ongoing violence (http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insidestory/2017/07/war-famine-cholera-yemen-170713175556509.html). If the violence in Yemen is a barrier to the UN's ability to intervene, other charities are likely also inhibited in preventing famine in Yemen.

A recent hearing the US Congress described Yemen's situation as already "famine like" ( https://www.devex.com/news/senate-hearing-urges-diplomatic-pressure-in-famine-response-90694) Recents pledges to let food flow may or may not pan out (http://www.news-sentinel.com/news/us-and-world/ap-interview-yemen-factions-said-to-have-pledged-easing-aid_20170727&profile=-1)
There's a lot of diplomatic action around this issue so it's a live situation that could trigger if the Saudis tighten the blockade further. Ongoing fights in Yemen, increase in cholera, world opinion looking the other way, interruption in agriculture

Pro arguments
-Yemen is dependent on food imports and is under blockade
-disruption of agriculture, infrastructure, transportation & markets due to 4 yrs of war. . . everything is getting worse, not better!
-military situation is worsening conditions in some areas, impacting agriculture, infrastructure, transportation & markets
-only 20% of need has been funded, according to some sources
-inadequate aid:  7m are at risk of famine but only about 5m are receiving assistance
-drought conditions - possibly inadequate rain during rainy season
-the way this question is worded;  it doesn't require a declaration of famine. Con arguments
-this is not the lean season
-October FEWS Net reports (post harvest) tend to be less dire
-the headlines may focus on the cholera epidemic
-the word "famine" doesn't appear in their headlines very often
-reports are not often country-specific so "Yemen" may not appear in the headline

FEWS NET is already classifying a significant portion of Yemen as either in a crisis or emergency, with the october-january forecast showing a dramatic increase. While they're not directly forecasting famine by October, the prospect of a headline containing the word "famine" is well within the realm of the probable.
Yemen is already in varying pre-famine stages.

Per the FEWS Yemen site of August 10, 2017, using the IPC classification system, no part of Yemen has minimal food insecurity.  The entire nation is viewed as IPC 2.0 -
 Acute Food Insecurity Phase.  For the near term - June-September 2017 - in stressed, crisis, or emergency food insecurity.  The majority of the population areas are either in an Emergency condition IPC Phase 3, or a Crisis condition, IPC Phase 4, and of the areas in Crisis, FEWS NET notes that the population areas would "likely be at least one phase worse without current or programmed humanitarian assistance."  To add to the insecurity, there is a severe cholera outbreak that has not abated, and there is ongoing civil war.  FEWS states that if humanitarian assistance is interrupted, delayed, or blocked through ports of Al Hudaydah and Salif, disrupting delivery of food to populations in most need, this could lead to famine.  However, FEWS also states that "at current funding and assistance levels, WFP expects to continue providing assistance through October 2017."  Thus, the question becomes how likely is it that food will continue to reach a predicted level of need.  Will the number of people in need increase due to cholera, war, and weak rains?  This seems likely.  Will humanitarian aide be increased to meet increased need?  Unknown; partially dependent on needs elsewhere, ability to deliver aide.  Will aide delivery be disrupted?  Very likely.

Consider this a high possibility:  While FEWS NET continues to acknowledge that Yemen is at risk of famine, there will be the possibility of ‘famine’ and ‘Yemen’ appearing in the food security alert. As they stated in this global alert: “Famine risk will not fully recede until substantive efforts are made to resolve ongoing conflict and improve access” (http://www.fews.net/global/alert/june-2017) 
The last alert issued solely about Yemen was in January 2017, though updates have been given since then - the Cholera epidemic would likely prompt another alert due to the increasing infant mortality. As @weakin said: “WFP expects to continue to provide assistance through to October 2017”, and if military operations scale up like the operation launched last week, I would expect FEWS NET would issue a potential for famine due to accessibility. 
“Mid-June, the Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) reported the 2017 Yemen Humanitarian Response Plan was only 20% funded.” This lack of funding would also warrant a Food Security Alert for a rapid assistance response to prevent famine.  That being siad, the areas that FEWS NET projects are at high risk of IPC Phase 4, were in the top range for government populations reached with aid. (http://www.fews.net/sites/default/files/documents/reports/YE_OL_2017_06_final.pdf)  Military operations: 
The largest military operation in Yemen, since 2016, began last week in Shabwa province: “and includes about 2,000 Yemeni forces backed by dozens of advisors from the UAE and U.S. Special Operations Commandos…The Shabwani Elite are in the process of securing major cities in the province - such as Azzan, Ataq and Jardan - from Qaeda militias and are also conducting clearing operations in the surrounding areas.” 
(https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/06/world/middleeast/yemen-qaeda-shabwa-province.html?_r=0) 
This led to Al-Qaeda retreating from Shabwa province, according to an article: “the Jihadists appear to have moved even further south into neighbouring Abyan province” (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/al-qaeda-forced-retreat-yemen-government-elite-squad-attack-2063143791) 
Whilst Shabwa ranges in ‘High priority convergence’ to ‘FSAC Priory District - Category 2’, Abyan province ranges from “High priority convergence’ to ‘FSAC Priority District - Category 1’, hence Abyan is at greater risk.(Page 7 -http://www.fews.net/sites/default/files/documents/reports/YE_OL_2017_06_final.pdf_. So, as areas in Shabwa province may see an increase humanitarian assistance, Al-Qaeda in Abyan province may lead to greater insecurity.

FEWS Net current analysis is that parts of Yemen are in Stage 3 and 4 of their food shortage scale (http://www.fews.net/east-africa/yemen).  They're predicting the shortages will continue even though the country is beginning it's 2nd harvest season and that these shortages will increase the risk of cholera, estimating that many level 3 areas will turn to level 4 areas by Oct-Jan.  Their current status puts Yemen "at risk of famine" and a headline with that warning was issued in their Food Security Outlook report in March.  That report period runs from February-September.  90% of Yemen's food supply comes from food imports & the country remains under blockade from land and water (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yemeni_Civil_War_(2015%E2%80%93present)). 
 This region is predicted to remain at risk, and news indicates that Saudi barricades and delays for humanitarian aid are ongoing and may continue, that 40% of hospitals are down or limited in what they can do to help.  Based on FEWS Net reporting history, a follow up Food Security Report for the Oct-Jan period is typical for at-risk areas.  Historically, October reports for in areas immediately post-harvest tend to be more positive and less dire sounding about risks than the Feb-April status reports.  Unless the situation worsens and the risk of famine increases for Yemen specifically to merit its own report or for the general region of northeast Africa, the headline will probably not include the word "famine" and "Yemen" specifically and other terms to return focus to level 3 or 4 risk will be used.  However, if predicted combinations of medical and food shortages continue and worsen, or if the threat of level 5 food shortage increases for the Oct-Feb period, a headline with both "Yemen" and "famine is probable..  It seems from recent political situations that there is little indication that a general trend of fall harvests will reduce the problems in Yemen, and for the last 2 years, the conflict has persisted throughout the year with targeted military activity in Sept or Oct.  Therefore it seems probable that the the situation will get worse and that a headline indicating worsening conditions/greater need will be issued in the Oct round of FEWS Food Security Outlook reports.

Based on latest FEWS Net report and prior forecaster comments.

According to the FEWS NET site, an update regarding Yemen noted in the following in response to Assistance needs remain very high amidst ongoing conflict and a major cholera outbreak (June 2017 to January 2018)" The FEWS NET site stated:   "Large-scale humanitarian assistance continues to play an important role in reducing the severity of acute food insecurity outcomes in Yemen. Although needs remain higher than current assistance levels, WFP reached approximately 4.4 million people in May and 5.3 million people in June with rations meeting between 60 and 100 percent of beneficiaries’ monthly consumption needs. At current funding and assistance levels, WFP expects to continue providing assistance through October 2017."   http://www.fews.net/east-africa/yemen The Notation the continuation of assistance is expected through October 2017.  Although a dire situation, I don't expect a headline change to reflect a change in Acute Food Insecurity Phase to Level 5 (Famine). Additionally, there appears to be more focus on the Cholera Outbreak which may be the focal point of any updated headline.
It is a matter of when, not if, that there will be such a headline.
Famine is a strong designation which carries with it major consequences for aid actors. As a result, the FSA will be cautious and will likely not pull the trigger in October.
While Yemen is facing a food crisis that could reach a tipping point, it seems to get lumped in with other areas in the region also with food insecurity.
